title: Simple circuits - does S1 or S2 light the bulb

content.question: The circuit shown contains a battery <math alttext="B" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">B</mi></math>, a lightbulb <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">L</mi></math>, a resistor <math alttext="R" overflow="scroll"><mi mathvariant="normal">R</mi></math>, and two switches <math alttext="S sub 1" overflow="scroll"><msub><mtext>S</mtext><mtext>1</mtext></msub></math> and <math alttext="S sub 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><msub><mtext>S</mtext><mtext>2</mtext></msub></mstyle></math>. Both switches are initially open. Which switch must be closed in order for the lightbulb to light, and what evidence or reasoning supports the claim?

choices.label: Switch <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> must be closed. The resistor is not part of a closed electrical loop if Switch <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is open.

Switch <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> must be closed. The battery is not part of a closed electrical loop if Switch <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is open.
Switch <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> must be closed. The bulb is not in a loop by itself if Switch <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is open.
Switch <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> must be closed. The bulb does not have two paths to the battery if Switch <math alttext="2" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn></math> is open.

content.answer: Switch <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> must be closed. The battery is not part of a closed electrical loop if Switch <math alttext="1" overflow="scroll"><mn>1</mn></math> is open.
